author: bridge-bot
content:
<nicoserranop> Hi all :) I was working on an coordinator API server in NodeJS but I think the Rust approach is more secure. In case it is useful for you, here is the repository:

https://github.com/zkparty/trusted-setup-api

The documentation is here:

https://hub.apitree.com/NicoSerranoP/Trusted-Setup-API/


I was using artillery.io to test the API with multiple requests and user flows. It is super useful and when we have the Rust coordinator finished I could help out setting up Artillery to test it :D

author: bridge-bot
content:
<Recmo> > <Recmo>  Ha, that‚Äôs all benchmark code. Server is not implemented, but the crypto code is pretty much done with optimizations, benches and tests. (re @kevaundray: Skimmed the code, nice to see you also using axum üôÇ 

One suggestion I'd say is to not directly have any curve related code in the coordinator crate like arb_fr. The coordinator only needs to care about the state transition from one state to another state. That state itself can be anything, as long as the coordinator can check the transition.


So something like this could be an interface:


fn default_state() -> State
fn check_state_transition(current_state : State, new_state : State, witness : Witness) -> bool


With that in mind, we can probably remove the part where the coordinator contributes first before launching the server, or maybe I'm misinterpretting that part?)

author: bridge-bot
content: <Recmo> Crypto is also all in a separate library, so easy to integrate in a coordinator server or (wasm) client.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<CarlBeek> > <CarlBeek>  I would prefer not to offer this and just make the lobby size massive (64 or 128k) something we'll feasibly not hit (so we don't need to implement the UX for it) (re @kevaundray: I don't have strong opinions on either approach tbh. The change would entail adding a new endpoint /lobby/join and the coordinator would need to keep a separate list of users who are not in the lobby but are signed in.

@CarlBeek and @trent_vanepps what were your thoughts?)

author: bridge-bot
content: <Recmo> @kevaundray @CarlBeek  are you available for a call today?

author: bridge-bot
content: <kevaundray> > <kevaundray>  Yep, I guess that code will be moved into the crypto crate? (re @Recmo: Ha, that‚Äôs all benchmark code. Server is not implemented, but the crypto code is pretty much done with optimizations, benches and tests.)

author: bridge-bot
content: <Recmo> no, it can be removed

author: bridge-bot
content:
<kevaundray> > <kevaundray>  I think Chiali's point was not about the UX of users not being able to login with a full lobby, but about the fact that once users login, they need to start pinging the coordinator for a spot. (So there is no state where you login and then choose to join the lobby)

I don't know how beneficial this state of being logged in, I just get the impression that its a more relaxed UX, which may or may not be what we are looking for (re @CarlBeek: I would prefer not to offer this and just make the lobby size massive (64 or 128k) something we'll feasibly not hit (so we don't need to implement the UX for it))

content: <kevaundray> > <kevaundray>  Does 3PM or 4PM UTC work? (re @Recmo: @kevaundray @CarlBeek  are you available for a call today?)

content: <philzip> > <philzip>  yes works! (re @Recmo: @philzip Grzegorz Marcin should also join if they can, we‚Äôre all working on coordinator/participant at the moment.)

author: chiali
content:
yeah, 
if we can increase the size of lobby, then one issue is gone.
but still if user login, then we through them right into lobby, it feels harsh.
also there is pre-step (input secret), I believe we want them to enter before get into the lobby.
making good UX is also = making the good technology shine, so how about I make lo-fi prototype for option A (as 2 state) option B (as 3 states, like what I propose) then we can see which one feels better?
<@550420431744794624> <@427491045308235776> üòÑ

author: bridge-bot
content:
<kevaundray> > <kevaundray>  For the random secret part, we'd need to tell users that before they login they need to keyboard smash for some user entropy. 

Because once they enter the lobby, they need to keep pinging the coordinator, and if they get the contribution spot immediately, they would be wasting time entering entropy (re @kzg_ceremony_bot: <Chiali> [reply]: yeah, 
if we can increase the size of lobby, then one issue is gone.
but still if user login, then we through them right into lobby, it feels harsh.
also there is pre-step (input secret), I believe we want them to enter before get into the lobby.
making good UX is also = making the good technology shine, so how about I make lo-fi prototype for option A (as 2 state) option B (as 3 states, like what I propose) then we can see which one feels better?
@Carl @Kev üòÑ)
